description:
Arthrobacter ginkgonis is a species of bacteria that was first isolated from the rhizosphere (the soil surrounding plant roots) of the Ginkgo biloba tree, a living fossil plant species. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium that belongs to the genus Arthrobacter.

Arthrobacter ginkgonis is characterized by its ability to form coccoid or rod-shaped cells, depending on the growth phase. It is capable of utilizing a variety of organic compounds as carbon and energy sources, including carbohydrates, amino acids, and organic acids.

This species has been found to possess several interesting features, such as the production of carotenoid pigments, which can contribute to its ability to survive in various environmental conditions. Additionally, Arthrobacter ginkgonis has shown potential applications in bioremediation, due to its ability to degrade certain pollutants and xenobiotic compounds.

Further research on Arthrobacter ginkgonis may provide insights into its ecological roles, metabolic capabilities, and potential biotechnological applications, particularly in the context of its association with the ancient Ginkgo biloba tree.
